Award.AwardTitle: SBIR Phase I: Advanced in-home technologies for infant thermoneutrality
Award.AbstractNarration:
The broader impact of this Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I Project is to enhance the well-being of babies and the quality of life of their caregivers and/or parents. Each week more than 2.5 million members of "Generation Alpha" are born globally to parents who expect and require technology driven feedback and support. Currently, this is not available in the area of sleep-time clothing choices, and so the ambiguous burden of these "art"-based decisions bears heavily on the minds of new parents. Medical bodies warn about limited capacity for infants to thermoregulate and the link between overheating and Sudden Infant Death Syndrome (SIDS). Under-dressing is also problematic and can result in serious infant hypothermia. Caregivers are educated that they must dress babies optimally, as over or under-dressing babies can lead to significant problems, but they are not armed with any technologies to do so. We will develop a system of advanced technologies to scientifically guide and quantify the right sleep-time choices, leading to optimal conditions for safe, regenerative and developmental growth, while alleviating the burden of doubt from the caregiver. Uniquely, we will couple advanced technologies with an engaging education platform to deliver a highly impactful product, designed to immediately capture a sizable portion of the rapidly growing $23 billion USA baby care industry.

The proposed project will develop advanced technologies capable of determining the thermal resistance of baby sleep clothes and sleep-sacks, and evaluating suitability with respect to the measured conditions of the sleep environment. Developed technologies will be deployed at the consumer level, in-home. Current technologies for measuring the thermal resistance of fabrics are prohibitively expensive, time consuming and laboratory based. Rapidly and robustly approximating to this technology for in-home and portable deployment is extremely complex. Research objectives include exploring and developing a variety of novel ways to characterize the physical properties of fabrics as they relate to thermal resistance, using complementary sensor-based suites to create new technologies, and creating powerful multifaceted algorithms that synergistically combine inputs and make deterministic conclusions. Results will be comparatively analyzed and the user will be provided with guidance to assist their choices through a graphical interface that also provides other state-of-the-art sleep-time education information, reaffirming best practices, right where they are vitally needed, at the point of sleep-time.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This Small Business Innovation Research Phase I project supported the development of advanced technologies to reduce the risk of life-threatening infant overheating at sleep time, provide specific safe-sleep education, reduce caregiver anxiety and improve family well-being.

Including Sudden Infant Death Syndrome, there are 3500 sleep-related infant deaths annually in the US.  Caregivers are warned about the dangers of inappropriate sleep-time choices and the importance of creating safe sleep environments, but don't know how.  To solve this complex problem, we researched and developed new technologies and integrated them into a hand-held prototype product that we branded, 'Neut'.  Neut introduces the all-important concept of thermal neutrality to parents in an unintimidating way, and uses it as a central idea in helping guide caregivers in creating safe sleep environments for their babies.

Neut is supported by a suite of cutting-edge technologies developed as a result of this project.  As its primary feature, Neut rapidly evaluates and assesses the thermal properties of sleep clothes while simultaneously measuring ambient conditions to provide the user with guidance on finding a thermodynamic match. In other words, it determines the appropriateness of a sleepwear selection for the particular room conditions to ensure parents dress their infant correctly for sleep time. Compared to the measured abilities of caregivers, Neut was shown to reduce potential thermal resistance selection error by more than an order of magnitude.

The patent-pending tool we developed achieves new technological feats.  Determining the thermal resistance of materials was previously a practice requiring environmentally controlled laboratories and the operation of large, highly complex and time-consuming equipment by someone with advanced training and expertise. Neut changes all that with novel, non-thermal technologies that generate a virtually instant and reliable approximation of thermal resistance in uncontrolled environments with just a hand-held device operable by the layman. It's all made possible by pseudo-intelligent algorithms and an innovative interface we developed, that elegantly convey the results of complex thermodynamics such that any user can easily understand. Additionally, the software delivers targeted specific safe-sleep education based on data learnings to help parents gain more and more confidence with every use.

This project challenged conventional wisdom and deeply ingrained paradigms denoting that a problem specific to a particular scientific domain belongs to that domain, and therefore should be solved by those same sciences. By collapsing the boundaries of sciences and engineering and creative arts, and considering the problem from a scientifically agnostic viewpoint, a truly holistic approach has yielded numerous benefits and many unexpected results were observed. Unexpected levels of performance were achieved that begin to elucidate the potential power of both the deep-technologies developed--and perhaps more importantly--the power of the scientific approach itself.

Neut's unique technological approach empowers caregivers to personally mitigate risk upstream. As opposed to common reactive technologies in the baby-tech market that simply monitor and alarm when something's amiss, Neut proactively educates the caregiver and arms them with the tools they need to make safe sleep-time decisions.  It provides specific recommendations, guidance and reassures caregivers. This empowering approach is exactly what caregivers told us they wanted. It's truly novel, enabling caregivers to create safe sleep environments in ways that were not possible before this project. It provides safety and assurance through application of cutting-edge science.  This project funded the development of the deep technologies that enable Neut, and Neut enables infant safe-sleep and improves family well-being.
